utterances: Well, Fred Bergsten, thanks for talking with us once again.
Glad to do it.
That's Fred Bergsten, director for the Peterson Institute for International Economics in Washington D.C.
I was in a grocery store one night this week when a sturdy young man approached me with a smile.
Do you remember me, he asked.
Bini.

Bini - Erblin Mehmataj was a bony-shouldered nine-year-old boy with a full, toothy grin who lived in an Albanian Muslim housing complex in which we stayed in Pristina to cover the war in Kosovo in 1999.

Bini and his friend Vesa were among the kids who would play in the housing block when there were no bombs going off, and sometimes even when there were, which reminded us how war brings everyday life to a grinding, bloody halt, but it cannot stop children from playing.

If you come to our website, NPR.org, you'll find a picture of us with Bini and Vesa, who is the young woman with a tennis racket, which she held as she walked around as a sign of adolescence sophistication, I always thought, and a reminder of normal life.
Bini - Erblin - is doing great now, getting his Ph.D. in math at a prestigious American school.
I've thought of the kids we played with in Pristina over the years, but especially now, as another debate is underway over the merits and morality of U.S.
military action that's aimed at stopping a war crime.
The Albanian Muslim families we lived among hailed the U.S.
bombers overhead and the British paratroopers who rolled into the housing block after the Serb retreat, because they'd lived through years of brutality under Slobodan Milosevic's regime.

Human Rights Watch would eventually report that about 500 civilians died in the NATO bombing, and the Milosevic government trumpeted those deaths while Serb paramilitary units reportedly slaughtered more civilians as they withdrew.
But the people in our apartment block had seen thousands die in what was called ethnic cleansing of Muslim areas.

They tended to forgive NATO its lethal mistakes - a misguided bomb that fell on a house of innocent people - if they also blew up the Security Police headquarters in which so much brutality had been plotted.
One of the reasons the U.S.

did not send troops to Kosovo or Bosnia was that so many Americans said they didn't want another Vietnam or Somalia, just as many now caution that they don't want Syria to become Iraq or even Benghazi, Libya.
History seems to serve up an example for any argument.
I wonder what, in a landscape already aflame with war, might give the young Binis and Vesas in Syria today a chance to play without fear.
(SOUNDBITE OF MUSIC)
And you're listening to NPR News.
Flora Lichtman's here with our Video Pick of the Week.
Hi, Flora.
Hi, Ira.
It's a beauty.
It's a reprise, a sort of a follow up.
Yes.
It's a sequel you might say.
A sequel.
Thank you.
I was looking for that word.
I was...
(SOUNDBITE OF LAUGHTER)
Do you remember the ever-popular where's the octopus?
Who could forget?
Who could forget?
That holds the record for our most viewed video.
I know.
It's half a million views.
It's much more than that.
Well, she's got the bunny ears for the top of the steps when he came down as the deranged Easter bunny, and we have the glasses.
We actually have an eyeball in case we happen to shoot our eyeball out.
We have a BB gun, but we weren't sure we're allowed to bring it here.
Brian Jones opened the Christmas Story House four years ago.
He already was making money off ""A Christmas Story"" by selling plastic leg lamps.
And the lamps, fishnet-stockinged and high-heeled, are ubiquitous in Cleveland.
We have in the actual full-size legs themselves, the nightlight, strings of lights, ornaments.
You can get an inflatable one that you can plug into your front yard.
Fabian and Jenny Sandoval(ph) put the dog in the car and drove to Cleveland from Falls Church, Virginia to buy a lamp.
And though co-workers thought they were crazy, they also sent along shopping lists.
The decoder pin, the soap and we need some of the ornaments and the nightlight, so we have to load up.
Christmas Story tourism dollars in Cleveland extend beyond the house.
They include two official A Christmas Story House Chinese restaurants.
The Cleveland Playhouse has just finished its 100th performance of the play.
And a local hotel promotes weekend packages that include goodie bags of Ovaltine and Lifebuoy soap.
Cleveland's Christmas Story pitch went even further this year.
A Pennsylvania family bid $5,200 on eBay.
What'd they win?
A chance to spend Christmas Eve and Christmas Day at the house the movie made famous.
For NPR News, I'm M.L Schultze.
From NPR News, this is ALL THINGS CONSIDERED.
I'm Melissa Block.
And I'm Robert Siegel.
As another month of feverish campaigning ends, here are some numbers.
In the tight race for the Democratic presidential nomination, Hillary Clinton has 1,035 pledged delegates and 241 and a half superdelegates.
The half comes from Democrats abroad.
Barack Obama leads with 1,187 pledged delegates, 191 superdelegates say they're supporting him.
Those numbers come from the Associated Press.
Hillary Clinton's future may be decided in Texas and Ohio, those primaries are on Tuesday.
We're going to hear about both Clinton and Obama on the campaign trail.
First to NPR's David Greene, who's in Texas with the Clinton campaign.
The campaign is feeling like a war in two theaters - Ohio and Texas.
And for Hillary Clinton, it's been about protecting her territory in both.
Wow.
Hello, Houston.
Clinton landed in Houston late last night.
She reminded a crowd of a few thousand of what she called the Texas two-step.
She said if they really want to help her, they must vote in the primary and come to a caucus meeting Tuesday night when more delegates are awarded.
We need you to come and be present and stand up and make sure your voice is heard, because Texas matters.
Texas will help pick the next president of the United States.
Clinton's effort did hit one bump this week.
One of her backers, Adelfa Callejo, an 84-year-old Dallas lawyer, was being interviewed on a local TV station, KTVT.
Callejo said many Latinos remain skeptical that African-American leaders look out for them.
And she said this about Obama…
Obama simply has a problem that he happens to be black.
The comment came a day after Clinton called on Obama to denounce and reject his support from Nation of Islam leader Louis Farrakhan.
Clinton heard about Callejo's remarks for the first time while being interviewed by the same Dallas station.
(Soundbite of interview)
Is this something where you reject and denounce her support because of her comments?
Oh, people have every reason to express their opinions.
I just don't agree with that.
I think that we should be looking at the individuals who are running, and that is certainly what I intend to do.
Clinton, like Obama, spent time in both Texas and Ohio this week.
The states have little in common, although there is this.
This is Rio Grande, Ohio.
Pronounced rye-oh grand, it's spelled Rio Grande, but it's just a small town.
Kent Haley is assistant manager at the Bob Evans Restaurant in town where Clinton stopped to chat up the breakfast crowd.
By the way, this is no ordinary Bob Evans.
It's the site of the original sausage shop that opened in 1962.
Bob Evans and his family used to live up in there in that brick house up there.
Haley said he, for one, is a Republican.
But, he added…
I may actually vote in the Democratic - since Ohio is open ticket, I may actually vote for Obama just because I really don't want to see Hillary in there.
Inside the Bob Evans, there were plenty of people who saw things differently.
Clinton worked her way from table to table.
